Is there a way to remove oleic and linoleic acid from oils? I'm asking because I actually make beard products like beard oil and beard balm and I try to avoid using oils that are high in oleic and linoleic acid, since those fatty acids have been shown to inhibit 5-alpha-reductase, which is important for converting testosterone into dihydrotestosterone, the hormone responsible for the maturation and growth of androgenic hair like facial hair.

Right now I'm settling with using oils that have very low levels of oleic acid and linoleic acid, but if there was a way to remove those fatty acids entirely, or even just reduce their levels significantly, that would be quite an amazing innovation for "beard science" lol. That would also open up the number of essential oils I could use for fragrances. Right now my options are pretty limited since a lot of essential oils contain fairly high levels of both oleic and linoleic acid.

I figured I’d post on this video, I work in a facility that refines oils and I have to say you were very close. One of the big problems with your method is that you need to do this reaction under vacuum to start. The reason for this is because soft oils like olive oil tend to form peroxides when this reaction happens. The final resulting almost black sludge is something that we deal with too. We call it residue and it gets wasted through the process. Finally gas chromatography is genuinely a lot better at telling individual fats apart. Testing them requires a twofold method though, the first tells you which ones are present between mono-s di-s and tri-s and the other tells you their percentage breakdown between the different fatty acids. I don’t want to get too specific because I could possibly divulge trade secrets, but this process just needs a couple of tweaks to actually work. I was actually surprised with how close you got.

(1) You should carry out the reaction in excess of glycerol to shift the equilibrium towards the product.
(2) Tin (II) chloride dihydrate (SnCl2·2H2O) is commonly used as a catalyst, since it turned out to lead to the highest glycerolysis yields.
(3) Since the presence of water is detrimental, use a water separator while esterification.

Hey Nile, I could be wrong on this. Maybe I don’t have all the required information. You showed your IR spectra at the 16:55 ish mark. Carboxylic acids are typically very easy to identify because they give very broad huge absorbances around 3700-3100 cm^-1 due to the O-H of the acid and hydrogen bonding. They are typically the easiest peaks to identify because they are large and broad. That does not seem to be present on the graph you displayed at about 16:55. Like I said, I could be missing some info about the spectrometer used and the parameters, but it does not look like a graph indicating carboxylic acid functional groups to me. I know your carbonyl peak came a little low for a typical ester carbonyl, but factors such as alpha or beta saturation/unsaturation, and other factors can shift the peak. It looks very possible to me that this actually is the graph of an ester rather than an acid. Just a thought, and like I said I’m certainly willing to be incorrect, maybe there is something I missed or don’t know here. You also have other indications such as liquid at room temp rather than solid, etc. Let me know what you think if you see this.

My best guess at what went wrong is that you boiled off much of your glycerol with the water. Because glycerol is hygroscopic, its boiling point should be altered when in solution with water. This would explain the fog created when you heated the solution. It would certainly take longer and might even require some vacuum, but performing the reaction at a lower temperature may allow the water to be boiled off without the glycerin. Otherwise, molecular sieves may be effective in pushing the reaction forward. I wasn't able to find any numbers to support this, but a forum on the issue had some good responses:
http://www.sciencemadness.org/talk/viewthread.php?tid=22180#:~:text=Glycerol%20can%20be%20dried%20by,the%20boiling%20point%20of%20water.&text=Glycerol%20can%20be%20dried%20by%20simply%20heating,the%20boiling%20point%20of%20water.

Hey man, you got something really really wrong in the IR spectrum (17:06). You DON’T have oleic acid in your sample. There is just no way. If there is indeed a carboxilic acid present in your compound, then it should appear in the spectrum: a wide signal centered near 3000 mm-1, wich corresponds to the OH in the carboxilic acid. You DO have a ketone (the signal at 1708.95 mm-1), but anyway, you can’t really make sure with this information that you have indeed a trygliceride in there. how do you remove glycerol from the soap?

20:14: "As I mentioned earlier, the cleanup was a huge pain and to get the things out I had to blast it with a heat gun" - well, next time try steam, hot water steam.
Set up the flask in exactly the same way, and using a small pipe (glass or metal one, doesnt really matter) introduce hot steam INSIDE the flask - initially at the top (meaning, close to the bottom of overturned flask) and then gradually proceed to the opening. After you'll remove as much of the stuff as possible (and I'd bet it'd be much more efficient than heat gun method), don't keep the flask for a "long and painfull" week in a base bath - just fill it up with a concentrated NaOH solution and boil it slowly for an hour of two; that should dissolve all the remaining gunk.

3:12 - "All of the oil is transferred to a small flask and I set up things fo a vacuum distilation" - umm, well... Why not STEAM distillation? Or, better still, a low-pressure steam distillation? As ZnCl2 is removed, AND the temperature of low pressure steam distillation would be quite low, there isn't much risk of hydrolisis. That method, the low pressure steam distillation is widely used for vegetable oils raffination, certainly in a case of palm oil raffination.

3:53 - "It is possible to just chop the soap into smaller pieces, but if you do this be prepared for a long and painfull dissilving process" - Hmm, I'm just wondering about that "painfull" part - you mean, like, literally..? ;-)

I think you used too much heating in both your esterification and distillation. Especially distillation at 400C is bad idea, since smoking point of olive oil is only 200C, which means thermal breakdown of fatty acid or glycerides can happen, the result of which is probably the black goop, Besides, this distillation won't help you get rid of fatty acid anyway if you can't measure the temperature, since oleate boiling temperature of 360C is quite close to 400C. I would IR the product before distillation.

POSSIBLE ISSUES WITH THIS EXPERIMENT

the fatty acids shouldn't solidify. Oleic acid is a liquid. If you are left with a solid then either A- there are other oils in the soap, or B- the Na+ was not neutralized by the HCl, and was still mostly sodium oleate, sodium linoleate, etc

as far as the color, the manufacturer probably used pomace olive oil. it is the leftover stuff from after the olives are pressed. it is of lower quality.

the glycerol needed can be calculated based on averages of the composition of olive oil, in this case pomace. then you would reference that with the stoichimoetry of the saponification value. The saponification value of olive oil and NaOH 0.135, i.e. for every 1000 grams of olive oil, you need to add 135 grams of NaOH

200C is way too high to do this reaction. quality olive oil decomposes at around 207C (its "smoke point) and begins to smoke, which is why it is not used in high temperature deep frying, but for lower quality olive oil, the smoke point is around 160C. Canola oil, which also has a large content of oleic acid has a much higher smoke point for some reason.

Some of the ester reaction might have occurred, but because of the decomposition of olive oil, i.e. the smoke point, it likely resulted in the white smoke. The smoke is likely acrolein

the zinc chloride probably further neutralized the Na+

after the reaction and time in the refrigerator, the product was indeed a liquid. however, it could have been the fatty acids without it being a triglyceride. draining the seperatory funnel showed that the bottom layer was somewhat viscous, more so than water. This is likely the result of he glycerin content. Since the glycerin didn't react is sank to the bottom with the heavier water layer. Glycerin is not miscible with triglycerides or aliphatic hydrocarbons. Therefore, it will separate with whatever with which it will mix, and sink to the bottom. The reason the fatty acids are black is because heating them burned them, and the discoloration is likely due to the smoke.

First, Zinc chloride is tricky. Having additional hydrogen around activates it, so you're going to have to provide excess hydrogen if you want a tri-ester; driving the reaction to eliminate all water (and thus all hydrogen) won't work because your catalyst will stop being a catalyst.
Complicating this, Zinc Chloride hydrogenates alkenes (most metal chlorides can). This is an industrial route for hydrogenation. The only difference between an esterification reaction and a hydrogenation reaction is the temperature and the concentration of free hydrogen. The need for controlled free hydrogen is why industry usually feeds zinc chloride with hydrogen chloride, rather than straight hydrogen gas.

Second, Speaking of temperature.... Fatty acids oxidize when over heated. Fatty acids with double bonds in them are especially noted for oxidizing at the position of the double bond. Esters are big molecules, relative to the size of the reactants. Hydrogenated alkenes are not really much bigger by comparison. Because of this, Hydrogenation happens faster at higher temperatures. Especially in this particular case. This is the difference between a thermodynamically controlled reaction vs a Kinetically controlled reaction and is a good demonstration of how a reaction can transition from one to the other.

I've made a ton of esters over the course of my PhD and never used the acid catalysed process. It's too hard to control. The easiest IMHO would be to convert the acid to acylchloride by refluxing it in 10 equiv. of thionyl chloride, distilling off the excess SOCl2. Then dissolve the residue in dry DCM, add your favourite organic base and top it off with glycerol and stir at rt. You'll have your ester in a few hours time. Also, it might be fun to monitor the progress of the reaction with TLC.

Suggestions:

Titrate the fatty acid mixture in aq. ethanol to determine how much glycerol is needed.
Use p-TsOH as the catalyst.
Consider an azeotropic distillation to remove water with a Dean Stark. You may need to use xylene or similar to achieve sufficient temperature.
If the above fails, try p-TsOH-catalyzed esterification to fatty acid methyl esters (FAME, biodiesel), then transesterification with glycerol and alkoxide catalyst while distilling off the methanol.

That is odd because a protonated carboxylic acid group will show a strong, broad signal in the IR. I even looked up an IR of oleic acid because I was curious and it shows this signal. There is an IR spectrum on google images listed as oleic acid, butyl ester that is lacking that signal, of course. With an ester, however, one usually observes a medium intensity, sharp signal at around 1050. It can be obscured due to other overlapping peaks, but you don't have those. p-toluenesulfonic acid does sound like a much better catalyst for this reaction.

And you may want to apply a vacuum to the esterification reaction, so that you can remove the water at lower temperature, without risking to decompose your glycerol. (Which I think is why your reaction failed.)

Also, I don't want to sound elitist, but I really wouldn't trust that paper you mentioned. Their temperature control was done using the hotplate's thermostat (so the actual reaction temperature is much lower than the one they indicate, but it's impossible to tell by how much), all they used for characterizing their products is thin layer chromatography, no NMR or IR, etc...

There's a reason it was published in one of the lowest ranking peer-reviewed journals.
